item.title: C++ performance: Case study of a limit order book
item.description: Introduction Link to heading In the high-stakes world of financial trading, where milliseconds can mean the difference between profit and loss, software efficiency isn’t just a nice-to-have—it’s a competitive edge. High-frequency trading (HFT) systems process millions of orders per second, demanding code that runs at breakneck speeds while managing vast amounts of real-time data. At the heart of these systems lies the order book, a dynamic structure that tracks buy (bid) and sell (ask) orders for a given asset, sorted by price and time priority.
